Experimental Results with IID Data â€“
We first present CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 classification results under IID data settings.
Table 1 and 2 show the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 results, respectively.
Note that the learning rate is individually tuned for each setting using a grid search, and we report the best settings.
In both tables, the first row shows the performance of FedAvg with a short interval Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6.
As the interval increases, FedAvg significantly loses the accuracy while the communication cost is proportionally reduced.
FedLAMA achieves a comparable accuracy to FedAvg with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6 while its communication cost is similar to that of FedAvg with Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime}.
These results demonstrate that Algorithm 2 effectively finds the layer-wise interval settings that maximize the communication cost reduction while minimizing the model discrepancy increase.

CIFAR-100 â€“
Figure 5 shows the learning curves for IID and non-IID CIFAR-100 datasets.
Likely to CIFAR-10 results, FedAvg learning curves are strongly affected as the aggregation interval increases from 666 to 242424 while FedLAMA learning curves are not strongly affected.
Table 9 and 10 show the CIFAR-100 classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings.
FedLAMA achieves a comparable accuracy to FedAvg with a short aggregation interval, even when the degree of data heterogeneity is extreamly high (25%percent2525\% device sampling and Direchletâ€™s coefficient of 0.10.10.1).
Table 11 shows the FedAvg accuracy with different Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} settings.
Under the strongly heterogeneous data distributions, FedAvg with a large aggregation interval (Ï„â‰¥12ğœ12\tau\geq 12) do not achieve a reasonable accuracy.

FEMNIST â€“
Figure 6 shows the learning curves of CNN training.
Likely to the previous two datasets, the periodic full aggregation suffers from the slower convergence as the aggregation interval increases.
FedLAMA learning curves are not much affected by the increased aggregation interval, and it results in achieving a higher validation accuracy after the same number of iterations.
Table 12 shows the FEMNIST classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings.
FedLAMA achieves a similar accuracy to the baseline (FedAvg with Ï„â€²=10superscriptğœâ€²10\tau^{\prime}=10) even when using a large interval increase factor Ï•â‰¥4italic-Ï•4\phi\geq 4.
These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed layer-wise adaptive model aggregation method on the problems with heterogeneous data distributions.

Experimental Results with Non-IID Data â€“
We now evaluate the performance of FedLAMA using non-IID data.
FEMNIST is inherently heterogeneous such that it contains the hand-written digit pictures collected from 3,55035503,550 different writers.
We use random 10%percent1010\% of the writersâ€™ training samples in our experiments.
Table 3 shows the FEMNIST classification results.
The base interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is set to 101010.
FedAvg (Ï•=1italic-Ï•1\phi=1) significantly loses the accuracy as the aggregation interval increases.
For example, when the interval increases from 101010 to 404040, the accuracy is dropped by 2.1%âˆ¼2.7%similar-topercent2.1percent2.72.1\%\sim 2.7\%.
In contrast, FedLAMA maintains the accuracy when Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases, while the communication cost is remarkably reduced.
This result demonstrates that FedLAMA effectively finds the best interval setting that reduces the communication cost while maintaining the accuracy.

Table 4 and 5 show the non-IID CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 experimental results.
We use Dirichletâ€™s distribution to generate heterogeneous data across all the clients.
The base aggregation interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is set to 666.
The interval increase factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is set to 222 for FedLAMA.
Likely to the IID data experiments, we observe that the periodic full averaging significantly loses the accuracy as the model aggregation interval increases, while it has a proportionally reduced communication cost.
FedLAMA achieves the comparable classification performance to the periodic full averaging, regardless of the device activation ratio and the degree of data heterogeneity.
For CIFAR-100, FedLAMA has a minor accuracy drop compared to the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6, however, the accuracy is still much higher than the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=12superscriptğœâ€²12\tau^{\prime}=12.
For both datasets, FedLAMA has a remarkably reduced communication cost compared to the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6.

We found that the amount of the reduced communication cost was not strongly affected by the degree of data heterogeneity.
As shown in Table 4 and 5, the reduced communication cost is similar across different Dirichletâ€™s coefficients and device participation ratios.
That is, FedLAMA can be considered as an effective model aggregation scheme regardless of the degree of data heterogeneity.

CIFAR-10 â€“
Figure 4 shows the full learning curves for IID and non-IID CIFAR-10 datasets.
The hyper-parameter settings correspond to Table 4 and 1.
First, as the aggregation interval increases from 666 to 242424, FedAvg suffers from the slower convergence, and it results in achieving a lower validation accuracy, regardless of the data distribution.
In contrast, FedLAMA learning curves are marginally affected by the increased aggregation interval.
Table 6 and 7 show the CIFAR-10 classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings.
As expected, the accuracy is reduced as Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases.
The IID and non-IID data settings show the common trend.
Depending on the system network bandwidth, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi can be tuned to be an appropriate value.
When Ï•=2italic-Ï•2\phi=2, the accuracy is almost the same as or even slightly higher than FedAvg accuracy.
If the network bandwidth is limited, one can increase Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and slightly increase the epoch budget to achieve a good accuracy.
Table 8 shows the CIFAR-10 accuracy across different Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} settings.
We see that the accuracy is significantly dropped as Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} increases.

CIFAR-10 â€“
Figure 4 shows the full learning curves for IID and non-IID CIFAR-10 datasets.
The hyper-parameter settings correspond to Table 4 and 1.
First, as the aggregation interval increases from 666 to 242424, FedAvg suffers from the slower convergence, and it results in achieving a lower validation accuracy, regardless of the data distribution.
In contrast, FedLAMA learning curves are marginally affected by the increased aggregation interval.
Table 6 and 7 show the CIFAR-10 classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings.
As expected, the accuracy is reduced as Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases.
The IID and non-IID data settings show the common trend.
Depending on the system network bandwidth, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi can be tuned to be an appropriate value.
When Ï•=2italic-Ï•2\phi=2, the accuracy is almost the same as or even slightly higher than FedAvg accuracy.
If the network bandwidth is limited, one can increase Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and slightly increase the epoch budget to achieve a good accuracy.
Table 8 shows the CIFAR-10 accuracy across different Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} settings.
We see that the accuracy is significantly dropped as Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} increases.

In this section, we provide extra experimental results with extensive hyper-parameter settings.
We fix the number of clients to
and use a local batch size of

in all the experiments.
The gradual learning rate warm-up (

) is applied to the first 10 epochs.
Overall, the learning curve charts and the validation accuracy tables deliver the key insight that FedLAMA achieves a comparable convergence speed to the periodic full aggregation with the base interval (
â€™) while having the communication cost that is similar to the periodic full aggregation with the increased interval (

â€“ For CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, we artificially generate the heterogeneous data distribution using Dirichletâ€™s distribution.
The concentration coefficient

to evaluate the performance of FedLAMA across a variety of degree of data heterogeneity.
Note that the small concentration coefficient represents the highly heterogeneous numbers of local samples across clients as well as the balance of the samples across the labels.
We used the data distribution source code provided by FedML (

FEMNIST â€“
Figure 6 shows the learning curves of CNN training.
Likely to the previous two datasets, the periodic full aggregation suffers from the slower convergence as the aggregation interval increases.
FedLAMA learning curves are not much affected by the increased aggregation interval, and it results in achieving a higher validation accuracy after the same number of iterations.
Table 12 shows the FEMNIST classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings.
FedLAMA achieves a similar accuracy to the baseline (FedAvg with Ï„â€²=10superscriptğœâ€²10\tau^{\prime}=10) even when using a large interval increase factor Ï•â‰¥4italic-Ï•4\phi\geq 4.
These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed layer-wise adaptive model aggregation method on the problems with heterogeneous data distributions.
